unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Distribution of Discrete Quantitative Variables
question_text: A distribution of a discrete quantitative variable

choices.text: Can give the reader information about center, shape, and spread.
Is always best conveyed in a boxplot.
Does not make sense in this situation; distributions make sense only for categorical data.
Can only be correctly displayed if the distribution is roughly normal.

solution:
The distribution of a quantitative variable basically tells the reader what values the variable takes on and how often it takes on these values. Based off this definition, one should be able to determine shape, center, and spread from this distribution.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect; the wording in the question clearly shows a single variable.

Choice 'C' is incorrect; a boxplot can be a useful way to describe data, but the plot will not be able to say exactly what values the variable takes on and their frequency.

Choice 'D' is incorrect; distributions are often displayed with quantitative data.

Choice 'E' is incorrect; distributions of all different types of shapes can be shown.
